Class Result<T>

This version of the Result type assumes the failure state will be a string. This is often the case and reduced the amount of type information required on function signatures

Inheritance
System.Object
Result<T, System.String>
Result<T>
Inherited Members
Result<T, String>.Success(T)
Result<T, String>.Failure(String)
Result<T, String>.HasValue(T)
Result<T, String>.HasFailure(String)
Result<T, String>.And<TOther, TResult>(Result<TOther, String>, Func<T, TOther, TResult>)
Result<T, String>.And<TOther, TResult>(Func<Result<TOther, String>>, Func<T, TOther, TResult>)
Namespace: FunctionalLink.Next
Assembly: FunctionalLink.Next.dll
Syntax
public class Result<T> : Result<T, string>
Type Parameters
Name Description
T

The type of the internal value if successful

Operators

Implicit(Failure<String> to Result<T>)

An implicit conversion operator for reducing the amount of syntax required for creating failed Results.

Declaration
public static implicit operator Result<T>(Failure<string> failure)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Failure<System.String> failure

The failure message
Returns
Type Description
Result<T>

A Result of T
Remarks

Typically, this operator is used like so:

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Success(a / b)
        : Failure("Cannot divide by zero"); // this Failure is implicitly converted to Result<int>

To avoid the implicit conversion, use the 'Failure' Option constructor directly:

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Result<int>.Success(a / b)
        : Result<int>.Failure("Cannot divide by zero"); // no implicit conversion is done here

Implicit(Success<T> to Result<T>)

An implicit conversion operator for reducing the amount of syntax required for creating successful Results.

Declaration
public static implicit operator Result<T>(Success<T> success)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Success<T> success

The Success instance to convert
Returns
Type Description
Result<T>

A Result of T
Remarks

Typically, this operator is used like so:

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Success(a / b)  // this Success is implicitly converted to Result<int>
        : Failure("Cannot divide by zero");

To avoid the implicit conversion, use the 'Failure' Option constructor directly:

public static Result<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Result<int>.Success(a / b)  // no implicit conversion is done here
        : Result<int>.Failure("Cannot divide by zero");
